dialogue: We Goats lack upper front teeth. Which accounts for the mispronunciation, Miss-- Glllinda.

Some of us are different. And there was a time, before you were born, when life in Oz was different. When one could walk these halls, and hear-- a Snow Leopard, solving an equation, or an Antelope, explicating a sonnet. So... when, and why-- did this change?
From what I've read, it began with the Great Drought.
Precisely. Food gre w scarce. When people are hungry, and-- angry, they begin to look for--
Someone to blame.
Yes, Miss Gllll--
Your lovely poppies!
Thank you, you're very kind. They're my favorite. They keep me cheerful... in these dark times.
Miss Elphaba-- please. Go and join your friends
It's alright, I have no friends.
Well. Maybe... one.
Miss Elphaba?! What are you doing here?
Doctor Dillamond, what you were describing just now-- could something like that really happen?
It is happening.
If you make it discouraging enough, you can keep anyon e silent.
But, Doctor Dillamond, if Animals--
Shhh!
You'd better go.
If Animals are losing the ability to speak-- leaving Oz-- someone's got to tell the Wizard.
Listen to me. You cannot tell another soul what you've heard and seen here tonight!
But-- that's why we have a Wizard!
Perhaps you're right.
Sorry. I must be-- catching a cold.
Oz bless you, Doctor Dillamond.
Not now, Miss Elphaba-- Please, everyone, take your seats, I've something to say, and very little time.
My dear students, this is my last day here at Shiz. You see, Animals-- are no longer permitted to teach.
What?
It's alright, Miss Elphaba... I'll be alright.
Listen to me--! You're not being told the whole story!
Doctor Dillamond--!
Are we all just going to sit here, in silence?!
